import React from 'react' import Sidebar from '../../components/sidebar/Sidebar' import Navsection from '../../components/navbar/Navsection' import './chapter1.scss' import { useNavigate } from "react-router-dom" const Chapter1 = () => { // ---------------- const navigate = useNavigate(); const transfer = (txt) => { if (txt.includes(":)")) { setTimeout(() => navigate('/'), 500); } } const submit = (e) => { e.preventDefault(); const code = document.getElementById("input").value; const data = { code: code }; fetch('/code', { method: 'POST', headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' }, body: JSON.stringify(data) }) .then(res => res.text()) .then(txt => alert(txt)) .then(txt => transfer(txt)) } return (

Chapter 1 Variables

What is Variable?

A variable is a box contains a piece of data information with a box name which makes it much easier to remember the address in store. Variables are stored in memory (store) and can be changed as the program runs (hence the name)

Variables have a type :

which tells us which type of information it stores. Before you can use a variable to store information we must first declare it

Primitive Variables:

8 types of basic information
type name example size
boolean  True/false  1bit
byte  Signed integer  8bit
 char  Unicode character  16bit
 short  Signed integer  16bit
 int  Signed integer  32bit
 long  Signed integer  64bit
 float  Floating point number  32bit
double  Floating point number  64bit

ReferenceVariables:

Objects with functionality Can be invoked to perform tasks Actually this types are the arrows pointing to the variable boxes

For example: chef.add (); BurgerMaker chef ;

Variable Declarations:

Type + name + (optionally) initial value

For example: int a; a=1; (equivalent to int a=1;)

String b=”Xin”; (it must be the “”, ‘’ is for assigning character) boolean d=true; float f =5.99f; char g=’d’

Note

If the variable is assigned twice, the value of this variable would be changed (overwrite) to the second value, So, if you want a variable to be not overwritten, we can use the keyword “final” For example: final int c=10;

c=12; //this would casue a error ‘cannot assign a value to a final variable’

Rules about Variable Names

An identifier (unique):

  • Unlimited length of letters (numerals, underscore, )
  • Cannot begin with a number
  • No spaces, dots, hyphens etc
  • Cannot be the same with a keyword

Exercise:

Please try to output this "Hello A Java Tutor!" by using the basic Syntax (System.out.println())
